title: Post-Cholecystectomy Bile Leak
diagnosis_topic: Bile leak from cystic duct stump or accessory duct after gallbladder removal
setup_script: A 52-year-old woman is postoperative day 3 after laparoscopic cholecystectomy for acute cholecystitis. She develops worsening abdominal pain, nausea and increasing bilious output from her surgical drain.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 115/75 mmHg, HR 110 bpm, RR 20/min, Temp 38 C.
Mild distension with tenderness in right upper quadrant but no peritonitis.
300 mL of green bile in last 24 hours.
WBC 14 K/uL, bilirubin mildly elevated; liver enzymes stable.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders CT scan with oral and IV contrast
dynamic_flow.reply: Shows fluid collection near the liver bed; no obvious bile duct injury.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults gastroenterology for ERCP
dynamic_flow.reply: ERCP identifies cystic duct stump leak; sphincterotomy and placement of biliary stent performed to divert bile flow.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident keeps patient NPO and starts IV antibiotics

dynamic_flow.reply: Bile peritonitis and sepsis may develop requiring reoperation.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about percutaneous drainage
dynamic_flow.reply: Consider for large collections; IR drains the biloma under imaging guidance.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses timing of stent removal
dynamic_flow.reply: Typically 4-6 weeks after ERCP once leak healed.
Inadequate clip on cystic duct, accessory duct of Luschka or clip slippage.
Watch for recurrent leak or cholangitis; follow liver function tests.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of postoperative bile leak via drain output and symptoms
Use of imaging and ERCP to identify and treat the leak
Need for biliary stenting and percutaneous drainage of collections
Prevention of bile peritonitis through early intervention
